title: Leaving big tech to build the #1 technology newsletter | Gergely Orosz (The Pragmatic Engineer)
key_insights: Target segments must be big enough to matter, small enough to lead, and a good fit with your crown jewels
Pragmatists buy what they see their peers buying - social proof is essential for crossing the chasm
Visionaries make poor references for pragmatists because they operate differently and create messes pragmatists have to clean up
You know you've crossed the chasm when you can survive without more venture funding - cashflow positive is the key metric
Each market phase requires a different playbook - using the wrong playbook in the wrong phase has opposite effects
Before crossing the chasm, focus on problem domain knowledge, not product demos or features
The compelling reason to buy comes from customer pain, not your compelling reason to sell
Start with one marquee customer for credibility, then find a beachhead segment of pragmatists with urgent problems
topics_discussed: Early market vs bowling alley vs tornado vs Main Street playbooks
Seven deadly sins of crossing the chasm
Compelling reason to buy vs compelling reason to sell
AI startup applications across lifecycle phases
Sales team composition for different phases
memorable_quotes: The tendency when you're in the chasm is, 'I just need more customers. I should take any customer I could find,' because we need revenue. It's like taking a match and running it back and forth under a log. It's not going to light the log.
Before the chasm, the customers you work with are people who say, 'We believe what you believe.' After the chasm, they say, 'I'm not sure about that, but we need what you have.'
If you're gifted enough to be able to start a software company and do something original, you're a scarce resource, so don't waste it.
frameworks_mentioned: Big enough to matter, small enough to lead framework

summary: Geoffrey Moore, author of 'Crossing the Chasm,' explains his seminal framework for helping B2B technology companies navigate the critical transition from early adopters to mainstream markets. The conversation provides tactical advice on target market selection, customer development, and go-to-market strategy for different phases of the technology adoption lifecycle.
